address: Cary Towne Boulevard Speed Limit Signs Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
There are no speed limit signs on Cary Towne Boulevard when coming from Western Boulevard/Farm Gate Road.

The speed limit on Farm Gate Road is 30 mph.  After turning left onto Cary Towne Boulevard there isn't a speed limit sign until you get to the "road to no where", then there is a 45 mph sign. 
 If you aren't familiar with the area, you would assume that the speed limit remains 30 mph. 

Cars exiting I40 at exits 291 east and west have no indication as to the speed limit.  There used to be a 45 mph speed limit sign on Cary Towne Boulevard right where the bridge crosses I40, but is was removed.

Please install speed limit signs where the east and west exit ramps merge with Cary Towne Boulevard.

Thank you.

I was extremely pleased to see that Maywood Avenue was recently repaved, as I drive on this road every weekday on my route to work.  However, if traveling eastbound on Maywood Ave from Lake Wheeler Rd, there are two sets of railroad tracks.  The slab between the first set of tracks WAS paved, which makes driving over it seem like nothing.  However, the slab between the second set of tracks WAS NOT paved -- which makes the transition between road and track a bit rough, which can wear down shocks/struts.  I was wondering if there was a specific reason this slab of road was left out in the renovation project.
summary: Road not fully paved in Maywood Ave renovation

description: Maywood Avenue was recently re-paved, which is amazing.  I drive down that road every morning -- and it definitely needed it.  However, heading eastbound in Maywood Ave from Lake Wheeler Rd, there are two sets of railroad tracks.  It appears that the slab between the first set of railroad tracks WAS paved, but the slab between the second set of railroad tracks WAS NOT paved.  This makes for a rough transition in a vehicle which can damage shocks/struts over time.  Is there a reason that this area was NOT paved in the Maywood Avenue renovation?

address: 6305 Belle Crest Drive Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
This saga started 10/28.  We discovered upon our return from a trip that extensive cable install/repair was underway involving ATT and Spectrum.  Apparently a new install of Spectrum services had interrupted ATT cable service.

USIC arrived eventual an re-mapped/labeled the routings.  When we left for a short weekend trip on Saturday, the ATT cable had been repaired and reburied.  There was no change in the Spectrum cable install.  

Upon our return this evening, we were advised by our neighbor that work had started sometime late Sunday morning.  At the point that we began documenting the extreme safety hazard we has multiple deep trenches and one hole within the utility easement.  These obstacles in addition to the large assumed Spectrum cable were not properly marked.  By that I mean there was a warning on only the street side of the work site.  The approaches to the trenches, hole, and cable were not provided with any warning to the home owner or residence of the property.  No one was identified as "owner of the work in progress".  The only indication of ownership of the work in progress was a damaged trailer licensed plate.  All of the previously existing road debris had need "blown" onto the properly of the home owner. 

Documentation of the pre-existing and current existing status of the "work site" can be provided in JPG media format.

address: 512 North Salisbury St. Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
I have some concerns about the crosswalk on N. Salisbury St. connected to deck 64. On the morning of 11/3/2017 around 8:24 AM, I was almost hit by 2 city drivers. 1 was driving a white ford explorer with orange tags and a decal on the side of the vehicle, driven by a white male and a white male as the passenger. It was so bad the lady behind the 2 drivers rolled down her window and couldn’t believe what she just saw. She did say it was 2 city vehicles. They were clearly not going the speed limit as they approached me and left me standing in the middle of the street. Luckily, no one behind me hit me. 

How many pedestrians have to get hit, or almost hit, for us to be able to have something we can push to cross the street, like the Dept. of Revenue has or a camera?

The materials yard for the Hillsborough St. renovation project has been located on Rosemary St, in a vacant residential lot, directly across the street from homes and adjacent to a multi-story apartment building. Heavy construction vehicles routinely slam tailgates, reverse over and over again blasting their reversing alarms, and dump and spread gravel all hours of the night, all week long in this lot. I started this post this morning, Friday 10/27/17 at 1:30 a.m., while there were two dump trucks idling in the yard, that just finished repeatedly slamming their tailgates. 

This is seriously effecting my sleep and ability to work and study, and I know I am not alone, the yard is in the middle of our neighborhood and my neighbors are all experiencing the same. I will continue to elevate this issue as I have been given the runaround from the city code and permit office. It's obvious the bottom line for the project does not involve social responsibility.

There are ways to mitigate nuisance noise from the project/yard. First, trucks delivering construction materials can be required to do so during normal hours exempt from city noise requirements (7:00 a.m. - 8:30 p.m. per Raleigh City Code Sec. 12-5007(g)) - this is not difficult to achieve and should have no bearing on project progress (materials required for the night's work are delivered before hand, not during nighttime work, excavated materials/waste can be accumulated in a large truck/trailer for delivery in the morning, significantly reducing heavy vehicle traffic during late night/early morning hours, and eliminating slamming tailgates during these times). Secondly, loud and obnoxious traditional style reversing alarms can be replaced very inexpensively (less than $120 each) on city owned equipment that will be operated during off-hours, with advanced alarms purposefully designed for these situations. Contractor requirements can be easily altered/enforced as well. 

I am posting this here as a last attempt on my behalf at an efficient remedy, before I begin to take the issues higher up the chain.

Hi City staff,

I am reporting a collapsed spillway where Peace St./Clark Ave. pass over a creek that flows into Edna Metz Wells Park (https://www.raleighnc.gov/home/content/ParksRec/Articles/Parks/EdnaMetzWells.html). I’m guessing this collapse happened Monday evening during very heavy rains. The creek is now dropping straight down after exiting the pipe under the street; digging a deeper and deeper hole. There is also a cracked wall to the side of the creek. I think this location on Peace St./Clark Ave. is now compromised, and will become unstable.

I have attached a photo from my walk through the park today.

While this situation is most pressing, there is also another issue in the park due to storm-water run-off from the street. There is a poorly designed sidewalk improvement to provide handicap access (a great goal), that is now allowing water to leave the street and flow down a path into the park. The gouged section of the path is over a foot deep and growing; I’m guessing the gouged-out section is 20 feet long. This situation predates yesterday; it’s been going on ever since the sidewalk was reconfigured.

Please let me know that you have received this message.

Thanks,
Mike Lindsay

description: I would like to ask that the City Council instruct the Police Department to enforce our noise ordinances in the downtown residential areas, in particular as it relates to muscle cars, motorcycles, and scooters.  I have lived downtown on Hillsborough Street for over two years and the noise has gotten worse and worse, at all hours of both day and night.   I have witnessed excessively loud vehicles pass by police as if nothing is wrong.  Noise pollution is deteriorating our City and will drive good families and individuals away from downtown.  Raleigh should be the showcase of our great state, warm and welcoming, not a nuisance town, loud and dividing.

address: 300 S Salisbury St Raleigh, North Carolina
description: Every morning on my bike ride to work cars will pull in front of me and park directly in the bike lane in front of the Wake County Justice Center, which has no parking signs the entire length of the curb. The security guard stationed outside of the building has never once told cars to move. Last week there was a box truck unloading for at least 10 minutes and the security guard did not tell the driver of the truck to move out of the bike lane. I confronted the security guard about it and he told me it is his job to get cars to move but that they never listen to him. I asked why he doesn't say anything to the drivers parking in the no parking zone/bike lane and he said if I had an issue to take it up with the folks inside the building. Please create new signage or a physical barrier or replace the security guard with one who will keep drivers from cutting off bikers and making one of the few designated bike lanes in Raleigh the most dangerous part of my commute.

address: 199 West South Street Raleigh, North Carolina
description: south Street and McDowell st

Over the past year or two, I've noticed a change in the behavior of our Raleigh Waste Management trash pick-up truck driver. In the past, the driver would stop his truck, pick up the trash bin, empty it, then put it back down in the same spot.

In more recent times, the driver picks up the bin, then resumes moving while emptying and releasing it, resulting in the bin's bouncing along the side of the road and ending up on its side (usually 10-12 feet from where it started). I predict that this is going to result, over time, in a significant decrease in the usable lifespan of the trash bins, along with a consequent increase in expenses to the city.

Please note that I'm not blaming the driver--I strongly suspect that this is an unintended result of some management policy that was introduced that is giving our route driver the incentive to try and complete his route as quickly as possible.

Is anyone in other parts of Raleigh noticing this same behavior? If so, please comment (and state your address) so that city officials can get a feel for whether this is an isolated or system-wide problem.
summary: Raleigh trash bins are taking a beating

description: Tree obstructing sidewalk

The sidewalks do not connect at this point on Wilderness Rd., which is very dangerous for pedestrians. Pedestrians are required to cross the street and to walk down the road a little bit to continue walking. Crossing the street at this point is very dangerous because of a combination of speeding cars, a blind hill, and overgrown foliage. The city needs to connect the sidewalk by extending it further on the Western side of Wilderness Rd. and incorporating a pedestrian crossing so that pedestrians can safely cross to the Eastern side of Wilderness Rd.. Since Wilderness Rd. was connected to Ray Rd, many people cut through the neighborhood to connect from Ray Rd. to Sawmill Rd. or Lynn Rd. I have almost been hit by a car numerous times at this point, and I know other neighbors have had similar dangerous experiences.

I live on Rose Lane and the end of the street which is a dead end. When there is excessive raining Our neighborhood is flooded in. There are approximately (60) sixty homes located past the bridge area that floods. When this happens we are unable to get out. We are unable to go to work, the children are unable to go to school and no emergency vehicle can come in if an emergency occurred. I have been living here for 16 years and this happens about 1 to 2 times per year. Neighbors stated that about a few years back stated they where going to clear a wooded area to make a road through but this has not happened. Could you address this issue and let us know what the City of Raleigh is planning to do or if it is even in the plan.  Some people have driven through the rushing water and cars stall out and some people have tried to walk through, one person was swept down the creek last year and had to be rescued. This is an on-going every year issue. You may contact  me at 919/508/1202 or 919/264-5566 or email me at debjohnson@rhaonline.com If this is being submitted to the incorrect department please send it to the appropriate department. Could someone please look into this issue and let us know what the community needs to do in order to get this problem fixed because it' not right that we are shut off from everything when this happens with no recourse.
Thank you, Respectfully Debra Johnson

address: Cary Towne Blvd & Farm Gate Road Raleigh North Carolina
description: An apartment complex named Bacarra opened recently at this intersection. A left turn lane which turns into the apartment complex was added on Cary Towne Blvd heading towards Raleigh/Western Blvd as part of this apartment complex being built.  I've lost count of the number of times I've seen vehicles blow right through this left turn without stopping at all, some not even slowing down.  I'm guessing they aren't noticing the stop sign way over to the right, and don't realize it's a 4-way stop.  The stop sign could probably be difficult to see when vehicles are in the straight through lane, but I've seen this happen with no vehicles in the straight through lane or anything else blocking the view of the stop sign from that left turn lane.  I've almost been hit two times in the last two weeks because of vehicles in this left turn lane not stopping, after I've come to a complete stop on Farm Gate Rd and then continue on with my left turn onto Cary Towne thinking they're going to stop - and then the person on Cary Towne making the left turn fusses at me when they're in the wrong for not stopping. The most recent incident was this past Monday, April 3. I was making a left onto Cary Towne and stopped on Farm Gate. A semi truck was approaching in the left turn lane into the apartment complex, I thought he was stopping so made my left turn, and he almost hit me because he wasn't planning on stopping for the 4-way stop like he was supposed to.  That latest incident was witnessed by a co-worker of mine who happened to be behind me in her car.  Something really needs to be done about this intersection before a wreck happens (if one hasn't happened already).  I don't know whether that should be better signage, 4-way flashers, or a full traffic signal light - but it needs something other than what's currently there.
summary: People in left turn lane into Bacarra apartments not stopping for 4-way stop

address: 1400 Quail Ridge Road Raleigh, North Carolina
description: The intersection at Falls of Neuse Rd. and Quail Ridge Rd. is VERY dangerous.  There are typically multiple accidents at or near this intersection each month, which have been witnessed by local residents and businesses.  Cars traveling north stay in the "right turn only" lane until the very last minute.  However, vehicles taking a left onto Falls of Neuse Rd. are not aware of this last minute decision, and will proceed to turn off Quail Ridge Rd.  There are a number of T-bone and rear end accidents that occur.  On 2/21/17, there was a worse accident involving two cards that resulted in substantial vehicle damages and personal injuries.  Given the open space at the apartments, there should really be a separate median that does not allow "right turn only" drivers to shift into the other lane at the last minute.

address: Reedy Creek Park Road Cary, North Carolina
description:
Umstead State Park is a very popular and safe area for bicyclists, but it is impossible to get across the airport from Umstead to to Briar Creek area. Adding a short bike rout connecting Umstead to existing airport roads would make a great path for riders and commuters between Raleigh and Briar Creek (and some parts of RTP as well!). 

With the current greenway connections, the only way for a biker to get from this end of Umstead to Briar Creek is to ride south to 54 and then west and back up to Page Road to cross under the freeway - lots of extra mileage and annoyed drivers on that route. 

Recent news coverage of the RDU airport authority planning process makes them appear very anti-bicycle. Adding to the greenway paths to allow transit across the airport would be a good idea to repair their image with Triangle bicyclists. 

Finally, it would improve security for the airport. Bicyclists carry cellphones and would be quick to report odd activities in areas that are not easy for airport security to patrol.

address: Lake Lynn Community Center Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
I have watched over the past 4 years as different stream modifications have been don't to keep the path dry.  Who ever is in charge of the "strategy" needs to regroup. 


This is the low spot on the path to lake Lynn from the community center.

This photo was taken yesterday. 

It hasn't rained hard In quite some time. Recent modifications to the stream bed have resulted in the path becoming part of the swamp.

If fixing the path is not an option can you please install a dispenser of clean dry children's socks and shoes in new or like new condition that can accomodate all sizes.

And a full service dog wash station complete with treat feeder"

And could this location be staffed with someone from parks and Rec that could gentle tamp feet with clean towels, take the wet shoes and socks, and clean them and dry them while we walk around the lake.

This person should be trained to say things like.....

"Sorry about the path always being underwater"

"Sorry your kids feet are wet"

"Sorry the dogs all muddy now"

"Did y'all still want to walk around the lake"

"Please don't splash your sister"

"I will carry you across the stream"

"I can carry your 4  children under the age of 5 and that wet dog, what's the doggies name?"

Thanks for considering my suggestions.

address: 632 Whitaker Mill Rd Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
A home is being built at this address, and the construction workers have taken to parking their trucks on the sidewalk each day. This forces pedestrians into the 4 lane road, needlessly putting lives at risk.

This has been happening consistently for weeks. As so much construction is happening on this road, it is unlikely the problem will abate naturally. 

I've asked the workers to park elsewhere, and have been met with intimidation and nasty words in response, and so I will now be reporting all incidents here and to the police.

I have made several reports about this to the police's non-emergency response number in the past, and again today, but the behavior continues. I will continue to file police reports until this public safety issue is resolved. If there is a better place to file such reports than with the police, please let me know.
summary: Construction vehicles parking on sidewalk daily

description:
Following up.... I was told:
" City of Raleigh 4 (Verified Official): Well Tara thanks for asking. Staff will grind the stump and offer a replacement tree.
03-30-2016 "

I STILL have not seen or heard anything and the stump is still there. Can I get an update on progress towards its removal, please?

Below is the original post-

In a Raleigh-initiative, the city planted 2 trees on our property/city property a couple years back. One flourished while the other got sick. Our HOA complained and we had to cut down the tree which only got to 7 feet high at it's tallest point. We are left with a 5" diameter stump between the sidewalk and the street which is city property. I had e-mailed the city but never got a response. The HOA wants the stump removed and we do not have the financial resources to do so especially for something that the city should be taking care of. Can someone please remove the stump?

address: Bent Creek Dr Raleigh, NC 27615, USA
description:
The intersection of the bike path along Lynn rd. As it crosses Bent Creek represents an on going hazard to path users. 

Cars must use this as a cut thru to Lynn rd and so the come to this stop looking left so the can turn right. They are likely unaware that there could be path traffic approaching from the right and almost always pull fully through the crossing as the come to a stop (if they bother to stop). 

This is made worse by the vegetation at the corner that obscures both path traffic and cars from seeing each other until they are at the crossing. 

It seems at the very least a sign informing cars to look for path traffic would be helpful.

It looks as though a "no left turn" sign was recently added to the west bound side of wade avenue near the Woodburn Rd intersection. This is great as there have been many instances of unnecessary traffic being created as a result of that turn being allowed.  However, the sign was put a couple car lengths before the actual intersection so that you can't actually see the sign if you've stopped to turn.

In two separate instances within a day of one another, I've seen drivers attempt and turn left even though the turn is not legal.  It may be that this sign is just too new and people haven't noticed it yet but it's also not placed in the most visible/convenient location either. The sign is at least a car length, if not more, before the intersection and on the right side of the west bound wade avenue.

A sign like this really needs to be placed closer to the intersection, possibly even on the left side. Being placed at the median would be much more ideal but the road is already fairly narrow already and no concrete median exists at that part of Wade Avenue.
summary: "No left turn" sign is not near the actual intersection

description:
It's great to see the new bike lanes added on S Wilmington Street and in other areas of the City!
At the Cabarrus / Wilmington intersection, the pavement markings for vehicles exiting the parking deck (south of Bank of America building) are confusing for motorists traveling northbound on Wilmington Street.  With the bike lane added on the east side, and the 2 travel lanes shifting to the west, the mini-skips in the intersection appear to be shifting the left lane into the right travel lane.  I walk by this intersection as part of my commute, and have seen some close calls with cars almost crashing into each other.  It appears that some mini-skips may need to be added in the intersection to guide motorists into their correct lane.

address: Neuse River Greenway Trail Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
Neuse River Greenway bridge over Bridges Lake, just north of the Milburnie Park access point.

I've previously reported (back in April) that this bridge is vastly substandard compared to every other bridge along the Neuse River Greenway (or the Walnut Creek and Crabtree Creek greenways, for that matter). The wood is warped and irregular and broken in some places, making walking or riding on it a very unpleasant (and somewhat unsafe) experience. It's as as if the contractor used wood from an old barn.

A city of Raleigh staffer responded that the decking on this bridge was scheduled for replacement this year, but to date there's been no work done. It's already mid-October (and I doubt this is going to be done in December!), so is there a status update on the planned work?

There is a wire or something tied around the power lines that cross over the street here.  This wire is tying the lines together but the end of it is hanging down.  This looks like a very poor job of trying to get the bottom line off the ground a little more.  Is the wire hanging down dangerous?  It appears to me that it is possible that it is hot (electrified) since it is touching several lines.  It is hanging down far enough where tall vehicles could possibly touch it.

I understand that the City wants to shut down nightlife and outdoor dining late night but are they also trying to kill restaurants during lunch?  It's been a couple of weeks that the street sweepers have been rolling up and down the street during prime lunch hours. I'm fairly certain they do this so they can be seen by the most people, but it's really not comfortable trying to eat lunch while being surrounded by these extremely loud and ineffective machines. I watched them today at lunch and the machines do very little to actually clean anything.  One of the machines is missing a front brush and the other machine doesn't even have the brushes actually touching the ground. It seems like they are all for show. 

Is there any chance the City could have these machines run during off peak hours rather than ruining diners experience during lunch time?

The intersection of Western Blvd and Boylan Ave remains a problem. In the last three days I have nearly been hit by a car that did not recognize the red light as relevant to their desire to turn left from Western onto Boylan and seen three other cars turning onto Western from Boylan run the red light for pedestrian crossing. Cars do not know where to stop (for westbound traffic on Western some go through the intersection and stop by the walkway others stop before the intersection, eastbound cars on Western turning left onto Boylan do not always stop before the crosswalk but seek to turn while the cars are stopped on Western). All of this is very hazardous for pedestrians and motorists. Is there some kind of signage to alert those turning onto Western from Boylan that they should be alert to the possibility of a red light at the crosswalk? Should the crosswalk be moved? Is there a sign to inform turning traffic from Western onto Boylan about where to stop or can an additional light be placed over the turn lane? I don't know the best solution, but this is an ongoing problem.

address: 201-299 East North Street Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
I reported this utility pole to Duke Energy Progress yesterday morning when I saw that it was leaning towards the street. This morning I drove by it again and is is leaning even further into the street. Yesterday it was not fully touching the nearby No Parking sign but today it is.

This pole has a transformer on it but no guy wire. It is slowly pushing itself out of its hole. When it finally goes over it will take out the tree next to it and probably a few cars, too.

I post this not because I expect CoR to fix it but for documentation purposes. Perhaps the city can convince DEP to do something about it as well.
summary: Utility pole at 200 E North St. leaning over street

address: Wilders Grove Lane Raleigh, North Carolina
description: The site is probably a private cemetery lot for deceased members of the Wilder family (for whom Wilders Grove is named, I imagine).  It is clearly visible from the gas station as well as New Bern Avenue.  There are four or five disintegrating graves enclosed in wrought iron fencing.  At least two graves are above-ground ones, and the cement "lids" of the coffin-sized cement "boxes" are slipping off or have been knocked off.  Very creepy looking!  That is, it would be possible to look into the cement vaults.  The fences are in disrepair, and the vegetation is overgrown.  Clearly, these graves or small "cemetery" haven't been maintained at all for a very long time.  If possible, they should be repaired and maintained and/or moved to a functioning cemetery, public or private.

address: Iron Horse Rd. And Wyndcliff Ct. Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
"Very Suspicious"... auto and individual (persons) activity:

Police officers have previously responded to numerous calls regarding suspicious individuals and automobile activities at homes in the cul-de-sac on Wyndcliff Ct. and on Iron Horse Rd. If you see anything or anyone suspicious, please contact the City of Raleigh police dept. 

As of 5/12, they have this activity recorded along with another unrelated complaint. The police report number is: P15-025435. Please refer to this number when you contact the police dept., and mention "suspicious auto and suspicious person activity" in this area. They have record of this already, but please call. This type of continuous activity WILL cause  long term problems for the neighborhood.

address: 3804 Old Coach Rd Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
FIRES set deliberately......by kids

(4-5) Children ranging in ages from 5 yrs old-13 yrs old are setting objects on fire in our neighborhood. On 5/ 11-5/12, they set long plant stalks and newspaper on fire under a dilapidated, plywood framed landscape type trailer w/ hitch loaded with dry hardwood mulch.  They deliberately started the fire under the trailer on dry ground.  The trailer has been sitting in the same location since the 2011 tornado. This is very dangerous! This is the second episode that our neighborhood is aware of and we are VERY concerned.
A 911 call was made yesterday and the police officer met with neighbors to discuss. The police report # is: P15-025435. Please contact the City of Raleigh police with any information regarding these kids and or any suspicious activity that fits these kids or this case.  The responding police officer urged anyone that has information regarding any similar activity or the whereabouts of these kids, to please call the police department. These kids have also vandalized and damaged our property over the last few months, and have also created dangerous driving "obstacle" conditions in the street on Iron Horse Rd.  This situation is only going to get worse. Please notify the police dept. if you see kids that appear to be unsupervised and doing harm to our properties.

When traveling in either direction on Glenwood Avenue, it is extremely unsafe to make a left turn onto either Whitaker Mill Road, or Fairview Road.  Drivers who attempt to turn left on the solid green light (not the green arrow) cannot see far enough ahead to know if the intersection is clear. This intersection is confusing enough without this added safety concern. I've seen many accidents here and was in one myself when I tried to turn left here. If you don't turn left on the solid green, the drivers behind you will get angry and try to drive around you, which is even more dangerous. The addition of a No Left Turn arrow on this traffic signal would solve this problem. I can't believe that hasn't been done already!
summary: "No Left Turn" signal needed at Five Points!

When driving west on W. Millbrook, there is an exit from Timbers Apartments on the left.  Residents frequently do these two things during heavy 5 PM traffic and there are frequent accidents and near misses at the Millbrook x Timber Creek intersection because of it.

1) They get in the eastbound right turn lane (marked with a yellow star in the picture) going the wrong way and trying to turn left into Timbers.  By the way, during rush hour, this lane is almost always backed up past the entrance to the Timbers, so it creates a standstill.
2) They come to a full stop in the westbound lane (blue star in the picture), waiting for the eastbound turn lane to clear so they can turn into Timbers.  They come to a full and unexpected stop during rush hour on a 45 mph road.  It's no wonder there are wrecks.

I am also attempting to contact Timbers management to get them to communicate regarding this issue to their residents, but in the meantime, I believe DOT or police should evaluate.  Whether there needs to be additional painting in the eastbound turn lane that makes it clear it's not a left-into-Timbers lane, or a sign, or additional police monitoring during rush hour, I'm not sure.  But the problem occurs there daily.  An officer in an unmarked car could sit there from 5:15 until 5:45 and probably witness a fender bender, several near misses, and a lot of flustered honking and confusion.

I really can't see how this apartment complex was not required to provide an additional entrance or notify their residents to U turn and take a right into the complex instead of causing traffic jams and wrecks.
summary: Daily traffic hazard caused by Timbers apartment residents

address: 1820 White Oak Road Raleigh, North Carolina
description:
I live on the 1800 block of White Oak Road in the Five Points neighborhood and we are in desperate need of some form of speed control. 

This block is a one way street. Cars park all up and down both sides for the street. The people that park on the street are both residents of the block, and visitors to the popular area and of the church. When cars are parked on both sides of the road (all the time), it turns into a single lane road. The problem is that cars FLY down this street and there is no room to swerve or avoid anything that may step out into the road or car doors opening. 

Cars fly down this road and if a child or animal were to step out from between parked cars, it would be a tragic and potentially fatal accident. What is worse is even if the driver did see someone stepping out into the road and swerved to miss them, there is nowhere to go to avoid hitting them. Many people walk down this street to get to the 5 points area and all of the restaurants and shops so there is heavy foot traffic.

Cars have clipped my car taking off the side mirror, and you have to take your own life in your hands when getting out of the car that a speeding car does not take off your door. 

This is a narrow street that is occupied by many families with small children and pets. 

It is my understanding that the street was made one way on this block to reduce through traffic but many if not most people using this road do not live on it. This is a straight and down hill street which already makes it easy to gain speed, but people fly going well over 40 MPH and it is dangerous in such a narrow space. Someone is going to get seriously hurt.

I would like to see a speed bump or two put in to slow down the traffic and make it safe for the inhabitants and guests of the neighborhood.
Need speed bumps/humps installed on glencoe road.  Traffic moves much faster than the posted 20mph speed in the neighborhood.

address: Neuse River Greenway Trail Raleigh, North Carolina
description: I was trying to commute using the Neuse River Greenway to my work on the NCSU campus, but this bridge across the Neuse near the Mial Plantation parking area was impassable. My (legal for greenways) tricycle was too wide to pass through the car blocking posts.  The federal spec for these is 5 feet post to post. Most of the newer  Wake County greenways are built this way.  I can easily pass between 4 ft posts so these must be closer to 3ft.  That is close enough to cause real trouble if two bicycles try to go together between them (5 feet is not).  Since I cannot use this bridge, I must go out on Shotwell Rd, and Old Baucom which have significant traffic.
summary: Bridge impassable due to construction of anti car posts

I just witnessed a tractor trailer trying to turn right onto Page Rd almost lose his load of construction materials due to an extremely low shoulder.  Tractor trailers do not have enough room to keep their rear axle tires on the road while turning right when there is on coming traffic on Page Rd.  

Short term fix would be to shore up the shoulder, but in the long run, this intersection needs to be re-engineered to accomodate the larger trucks that move through this intersection due to the FedEx Hub and other businesses that have grown up around this area in the last few years.
